question_text: Two days after delivery, a 3470-g (7-lb 10-oz) newborn has an episode of bilious vomiting. He has not yet passed meconium. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman; pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended abdomen. There is tympany to percussion. Digital rectal examination shows elevated sphincter tone; when the finger is removed, there is an explosive release of stool and air. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a massively dilated colon proximal to a narrowed segment of colon. Which of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?
content_preview: Two days after delivery, a 3470-g (7-lb 10-oz) newborn has an episode of bilious vomiting. He has not yet passed meconium. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman; pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended abdomen. There is tympany to percussion. Digital rectal examination shows elevated sphincter tone; when the finger is removed, there is an explosive release of stool and air. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a massively dilated colon proximal to a narrowed segment of colon. Which of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?
hint: The patient presents with signs of distal intestinal obstruction (delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention, bilious vomiting), and a DRE shows anal sphincter hypertonicity with an explosive release of stool and air, indicating elevated intraluminal pressure in the colon. X-ray of the abdomen shows megacolon with an area of distal narrowing. These findings are highly suggestive of Hirschsprung disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Hirschsprung disease, and recall its embryological origin.

answers.content: Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa
answers.explanation_why: Ischemic necrosis of the intestinal mucosa is seen in necrotizing enterocolitis, which can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting shortly after birth, However, an x-ray would typically show bowel wall edema, pneumatosis intestinalis, and/or free air within the abdomen (due to intestinal perforation). Also, patients typically have a history of bloody diarrhea (unlike this neonate, who has delayed passage of meconium), and the child would appear seriously ill with cardiopulmonary instability. Moreover, this patient lacks the risk factors commonly associated with necrotizing enterocolitis, such as preterm birth and neonatal asphyxia.
answers.explanation_but: Prolonged intestinal obstruction in Hirschsprung disease can also result in enterocolitis and perforation of the bowel wall.

images.title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonateMultiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

answers.content: Telescoping of intestinal segment into itself
answers.explanation_why: Intussusception, or telescoping of the proximal intestinal segment into the distal segment, is more common in males and may result in abdominal distention, bilious vomiting, and dilated bowel loops on x-ray due to intestinal obstruction. However, the small bowel would be distended (not the large bowel), since intussusception typically occurs at the ileocolic junction. Moreover, intussusception usually occurs between 5 months and 3 years of age; it is extremely rare in the neonatal period. Finally, blood in the rectum is often found on digital rectal examination, which was not the case here.

Intestinal malrotation can manifest within the first month of life with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention due to intestinal obstruction caused by Ladd bands or a midgut volvulus. However, x-ray would show a double bubble sign or multiple air-fluid levels proximal to the site of obstruction, in contrast to the distended descending colon seen in this patient.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is more common in males, may result in vomiting in the neonatal period. However, the vomiting is nonbilious, projectile, occurs following feeds, and usually begins 2–6 weeks after birth. An x-ray of the abdomen would show a distended stomach with minimal distention of the bowels. Other clinical features include decreased soiling of diapers (due to decreased urine output), as well as a hypertrophic “olive” in the epigastric region and/or a gastric peristaltic wave on examination.

answers.content: Impaired migration of neural crest cells
answers.explanation_why: Impaired migration of neural crest cells is the underlying cause of Hirschsprung disease. Parasympathetic neural crest cells migrate in a rostral to caudal direction, from the foregut to the midgut to the hindgut. Failure of the neural crest cells to complete this migration typically results in an aganglionic distal sigmoid and rectum (i.e., without the myenteric and submucosal plexus). As a result, there is hypertonicity in the walls of the rectum and sigmoid, and the internal anal sphincter fails to relax in response to rectal distention. The net effect is intestinal obstruction and dilation of the colon (megacolon). The diagnosis is confirmed via rectal biopsy, which would show aganglionosis, increased acetylcholinesterase activity, and/or hyperplasia of parasympathetic fibers.

images.title: Etiopathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease
images.description: The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

answers.content: Failure to restore patency to fetal duodenum
answers.explanation_why: Failure to restore patency to fetal duodenum results in duodenal atresia, which would also present with bilious vomiting and delayed passage of meconium. However, abdominal distention is typically not as prominent, and symptoms are usually evident on the first day after birth with the initiation of feeds. Additionally, the prenatal period is often complicated by polyhydramnios, and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a double bubble sign and absence of gas in the small and large intestine.

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.explanation_why: A mutation in the CFTR gene is the underlying cause of cystic fibrosis, which may result in abdominal distention and bilious vomiting due to intestinal obstruction caused by thickened, inspissated meconium within the distal ileum (meconium ileus). However, x-ray in meconium ileus would typically show small bowel distention or a soap-bubble appearance (Neuhauser sign).

images.title: Microcolon and bowel perforation in meconium ileus
images.description: Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileusMultiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.Blue overlay: ECG electrodes

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
hint: Carbamazepine intake is known to inhibit folate absorption in pregnant women.
learning_objective: Recognize the teratogenic effects of carbamazepine, and recall the complications associated with folate antagonism in pregnancy.

answers.explanation_why: Visceral malformations such as fetal renal dysplasia are associated with the use of ACE inhibitors during pregnancy, particularly if this use occurs during the second and third trimesters. Carbamazepine use, however, is not associated with an increased risk of renal dysplasia.

Neural tube defects, such as meningocele, are associated with carbamazepine intake during pregnancy due to maternal folate deficiency. Carbamazepine can result in maternal folate deficiency, which prevents proper closure of the neural plate in the embryo during the fourth week of pregnancy. Most commonly, the caudal end of the neural tube is affected, which results in spina bifida. Carbamazepine may also cause developmental delay, cleft palate, skeletal abnormalities (e.g., finger hypoplasia), and cardiovascular abnormalities. All women should receive folate supplementation during pregnancy, particularly when receiving a folate antagonist.

There is no antiepileptic drug that is not teratogenic. If a pregnant woman, or a woman wishing to conceive, requires antiseizure treatment, an agent should be chosen that controls seizures and is tolerated well by the mother at the lowest effective dose. Valproate, however, should generally be avoided in pregnancy.

Teeth discoloration is associated with tetracycline (e.g., doxycycline) intake during pregnancy. Tetracyclines deposit in the buds of developing teeth, and this can cause significant and persistent yellow-brownish discoloration of the teeth. Carbamazepine does not deposit in the teeth.

Sensorineural hearing loss may occur in a child whose mother took aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) during pregnancy, which can damage the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Carbamazepine use, however, is not associated with an increased risk of hearing loss.

Clear cell carcinoma of the cervix and vagina is associated with diethylstilbestrol (DES) intake during pregnancy. Although women exposed to DES in utero do not develop this tumor until around 20 years of age, abnormalities of the reproductive tract (e.g., uterine hypoplasia) may already be present at birth. As the use of DES in pregnant women is mostly discontinued, the incidence of clear cell carcinoma of the cervix and vagina is in decline. Carbamazepine use during pregnancy, however, is not associated with cancer.

Limb malformation is common in thalidomide embryopathy, a condition that is caused by maternal thalidomide use during pregnancy. It can cause phocomelia and/or micromelia. Although carbamazepine use can cause minor skeletal anomalies, such as finger hypoplasia and facial dysmorphism, limb malformations are uncommon.
Tricuspid valve displacement is a finding in Ebstein anomaly, which may be associated with prenatal lithium exposure. Carbamazepine use, however, is not associated with Ebstein anomaly.

question_text: A 4-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his father because of swelling of his left hemiscrotum. He has otherwise been healthy and is gaining weight appropriately. Physical examination shows a nontender left scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass increases in size when the boy cries but is easily reducible. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 4-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his father because of swelling of his left hemiscrotum. He has otherwise been healthy and is gaining weight appropriately. Physical examination shows a nontender left scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass increases in size when the boy cries but is easily reducible. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
hint: This patient's nontender, reducible scrotal swelling with a positive transillumination is highly characteristic of infantile communicating hydrocele.
learning_objective: Recognize a patent processus vaginalis.

answers.explanation_why: The inguinal canal floor weakens with age and is the underlying cause of direct inguinal hernias, which are commonly seen in older adults but are rare in children. Inguinal hernias may increase in size with increases in intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., crying, Valsalva maneuver) and will be reducible, but they do not transilluminate.

Lack of testicular fixation predisposes to testicular torsion, which usually manifests with sudden-onset unilateral testicular pain that radiates to the lower abdomen. Affected patients present with nausea, vomiting, and a tender high-riding testicle with an absent cremasteric reflex. The affected testicle does not transilluminate. This patient's transilluminating, nontender, scrotal mass is caused by a different scrotal anomaly that is not related to testicular fixation.

All patients with a scrotal mass should be evaluated for testicular germ cell neoplasias. These testicular tumors usually manifest as a solid, nontender testicular mass that is not reducible and does not transilluminate on physical examination, in contrast to this patient's mass. Moreover, testicular tumors typically only appear after puberty and are rare in infants.

Sperm collections in the epididymal duct, or spermatoceles, manifest as palpable, typically asymptomatic masses on the head of the epididymis. Spermatoceles may transilluminate but are not typically seen in infancy and they are not usually reducible.

A patent processus vaginalis is the underlying cause of an infantile communicating hydrocele, which manifests as a painless, fluctuant, transilluminate swelling of the scrotum. This channel is formed when the processus vaginalis fails to obliterate in utero, allowing for communication with the peritoneal cavity (e.g., accumulation of peritoneal fluid, protrusion of intestinal organs, etc.). A communicating hydrocele may increase in size with crying or the Valsalva maneuver (i.e., on increases in intra-abdominal pressure) but is often reducible, as seen in this patient. As such, all hydroceles must be distinguished from inguinal hernias (a palpable mass as opposed to a fluctuant mass).

Congenital hydroceles usually resolve spontaneously, but surgery may be indicated in prolonged forms to prevent an inguinal hernia.

Dilation of the pampiniform plexus is the underlying cause of a varicocele. In varicocele, the twisted and enlarged veins are palpable and often visible (bag-of-worms appearance). They may increase in size with increases in intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., crying or the Valsalva maneuver) but will not be reducible or transilluminate, unlike this patient's mass.

images.title: Varicocele
images.description: Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.

question_text: A new imaging modality is being tested to study vitelline duct morphology. A fetus at 20 weeks' gestation is found to have partial obliteration of this duct. Which of the following is the most likely sequela of this condition?
content_preview: A new imaging modality is being tested to study vitelline duct morphology. A fetus at 20 weeks' gestation is found to have partial obliteration of this duct. Which of the following is the most likely sequela of this condition?
hint: During normal embryonic development, the vitelline duct obliterates completely by the 6^th to 7^th week of gestation. Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct results in a Meckel diverticulum, the most common congenital gastrointestinal tract anomaly.
learning_objective: Recognize incomplete vitelline duct obliteration, and recall its complications.

answers.content: Protrusion of abdominal viscera into the umbilical cord
answers.explanation_why: Protrusion of abdominal viscera into the umbilical cord is characteristic of an omphalocele, which results from failure of the midgut to retract into the abdominal cavity during the 10^th week of gestation. Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct does not result in herniated loops of bowel.
Swelling in the genital region is characteristic of a communicating hydrocele, which is caused by a failure of obliteration of the processus vaginalis, not the vitelline duct.

answers.content: Discharge of meconium from the umbilicus
answers.explanation_why: Discharge of meconium from the umbilicus is a sequela of a vitelline fistula, which occurs if the vitelline duct remains patent. This fetus at 20 weeks' gestation has a partially obliterated vitelline duct.

This fetus will develop a Meckel diverticulum, which can cause bowel obstruction as a result of intussusception, volvulus, or a fecolith within the diverticulum. However, the most common location of Meckel diverticulum is the terminal ileum. Therefore, the proximal small bowel is typically dilated and the distal descending colon will be collapsed. Dilation of the descending colon is instead associated with Hirschsprung disease and anal atresia.

answers.content: Discharge of urine from the umbilicus
answers.explanation_why: Discharge of urine from the umbilicus is caused by a urachal fistula, which results from a failure of the urachus to obliterate, not the vitelline duct.

Patients with Meckel diverticulum are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients can develop lower GI bleeding as a result of diverticulitis and/or intussusception (the diverticulum acts as a lead point for intussusception). In some patients, the diverticulum contains ectopic gastric tissue, which can also cause lower GI bleeding as a result of gastric acid induced ulceration of the ileal mucosa.

The rule of 2s in Meckel diverticulum: 2% of the population, 2 inches (5 cm) long, 2 feet (60 cm) from the ileocaecal valve, 2/3^rd with ectopic mucosa, 2 types of ectopic tissue (gastric and pancreatic).

images.title: Meckel diverticulum
images.description: The Meckel diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct. The omphalomesenteric duct connects the yolk sac to the alimentary tract in the embryo (left image). The duct is normally obliterated by the 6^th week of intrauterine life. However, incomplete obliteration leads to the development of a diverticulum located approx. 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve (right image). The Meckel diverticulum is often connected to the navel via a fibrous cord, which is the obliterated part of the omphalomesenteric duct (middle image).

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S_2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of a large patent ductus arteriosus, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
answers.explanation_why: A single overriding great vessel is called a persistent truncus arteriosus. This single arterial trunk arising from the heart provides mixed blood to the pulmonary arteries and the systemic circulation. Pulses may be accentuated and bounding; however, oxygen saturation would be decreased in all extremities. Furthermore, if it is not diagnosed prenatally, it will typically present perinatally with symptoms of global cyanosis and heart failure, while this adolescent patient only has differential cyanosis.

answers.content: Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are often asymptomatic. In adults, larger defects may lead to a distinct left-to-right shunt, which can result in right heart failure, supraventricular arrhythmias, and pulmonary hypertension, and ultimately lead to an Eisenmenger reaction and global cyanosis. Differential cyanosis would not be seen.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
answers.explanation_why:
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to completely close postnatally allows blood to flow from the descending aorta back to the pulmonary artery (left-to-right shunt). In a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), this leads to volume overload of the right ventricle and the lung circuit. This increased blood flow causes pulmonary hypertension and irreversible remodeling of small pulmonary vessels, which may eventually lead to an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). This patient's palpable right parasternal heave and pronounced S_2 are evidence of increased right heart strain. In patients with a large PDA, the features of differential cyanosis occur once shunt reversal develops. Because the ductus is located on the descending aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, reversal of the shunt results in deoxygenated blood reaching only the lower body. Due to the rise in pulmonary pressure, the characteristic continuous machine-like murmur heard in patients with PDA eventually disappears.

Infants with PDA usually receive an infusion of indomethacin to induce closure of the duct, while in older children symptomatic PDAs are typically closed surgically or via percutaneous catheter occlusion. The presence of an Eisenmenger reaction is, however, a contraindication to a PDA closure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
answers.explanation_why: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect is seen in tetralogy of Fallot. The other features of this cardiac abnormality are pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is typically symptomatic in infancy and presents with tet spells and mild cyanosis in all extremities.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus
answers.explanation_why: Abnormal narrowing at the aortic isthmus is consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA), which would cause differential cyanosis if the CoA is severe (i.e., a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect) but this differential cyanosis would be evident from the neonatal period. In addition, patients with CoA have a brachio-femoral pulse delay rather than synchronous pulses. The symptoms of a mild CoA can begin later in life but in such a scenario, differential cyanosis would not be expected. Instead, patients present with features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headaches, epistaxis), lower extremity arterial insufficiency (manifesting with claudication and cool skin with faint or unpalpable pulses, but no cyanosis), and evidence of compensatory collateral arteries (e.g., continuous murmur over the back).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

question_text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
hint: Men with a history of cryptorchidism are at increased risk for testicular germ cell tumors, even after cryptorchidism has been surgically repaired.
learning_objective: Recognize teratoma in a patient with a history of cryptorchidism.

answers.explanation_why:
Testicular germ cell tumors are divided into two groups: seminomas (most common) and nonseminoma tumors. Nonseminoma tumors include embryonal carcinomas, yolk sac tumors, testicular choriocarcinomas, teratomas, and tumors with mixed germ cell histology. Pure teratomas typically do not cause an elevation in testicular tumor markers (beta-hCG, AFP, PLAP), which is consistent with this patient's laboratory studies. Teratomas are more common in children but are usually benign in this patient group. In adult males, they are rare but more often malignant.

Unlike hydroceles, testicular tumors do not transilluminate on examination. Typically, testicular tumors should not be percutaneously biopsied because a biopsy can cause seeding of malignant cells in the scrotum.
Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Sertoli cell tumors. Moreover, Sertoli cell tumors are very rare, accounting for < 1% of all testicular cancers in adults.

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Leydig cell tumors. Moreover, Leydig cell tumors are very rare, accounting for only approx. 2% of all testicular cancers in adults.

Yolk sac tumors are nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. While this patient's history of bilateral cryptorchidism puts him at increased risk of developing germ cell tumors, he is unlikely to develop a yolk sac tumor because it most commonly manifests before puberty. Moreover, yolk sac tumors are associated with an increased level of AFP, which is normal in this patient.

Testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in men > 60 years of age. It usually arises when non-Hodgkin lymphoma metastasizes to the testicles. This 30-year-old man is unlikely to have a testicular lymphoma, and cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for testicular lymphoma.

question_text: A male newborn is born at 37 weeks' gestation after spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother had no prenatal care. Physical examination shows a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis, 4 mm proximal to the glans. There is a 3-cm defect in the midline abdominal wall superior to the pubic symphysis with exposure of moist, erythematous mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A male newborn is born at 37 weeks' gestation after spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother had no prenatal care. Physical examination shows a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis, 4 mm proximal to the glans. There is a 3-cm defect in the midline abdominal wall superior to the pubic symphysis with exposure of moist, erythematous mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
hint: This male newborn has epispadias, a condition that manifests with a urethral opening on the dorsal aspect of the penis. Epispadias is often associated with bladder exstrophy, which causes herniation of bladder mucosa through the lower midline abdominal wall, as seen in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize epispadias and bladder exstrophy, and recall their embryological origin.

answers.explanation_why: Persistence of the urogenital membrane is associated with the development of posterior urethral valves, which, due to the fetus's inability to properly excrete urine, can lead to oligohydramnios. Severe oligohydramnios results in Potter sequence, which consists of craniofacial abnormalities, clubbed feet, and pulmonary hypoplasia. Posterior urethral valves can cause bladder dysfunction but are not associated with epispadias or bladder exstrophy.

answers.content: Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings
answers.explanation_why: Incomplete union of the labioscrotal swellings causes a bifid scrotum, which manifests with a midline cleft in the scrotum. Bifid scrotum is associated with hypospadias, not epispadias or bladder exstrophy. Any atypical genitalia findings in a newborn should prompt evaluation for a disorder of sexual development such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia or androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Misdirected growth of the genital tubercle in the posterior (rather than superior) direction during the 5^th week of gestation results in epispadias. It is very rare for bladder exstrophy to occur without epispadias, but epispadias can occur without bladder exstrophy.
If the gubernaculum does not involute, the testes may not descend properly into the scrotum, which results in cryptorchidism. This condition is not associated with epispadias or bladder exstrophy.

answers.content: Failed fusion of the urethral folds
answers.explanation_why: Failed fusion of the urethral folds during the 17^th week of gestation results in hypospadias, which manifests with a urethral opening proximal to the glans on the ventral aspect of the penis. Hypospadias is associated with inguinal hernias and cryptorchidism, not bladder exstrophy.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This mass will also move cranially with swallowing.
learning_objective: Recognize a thyroglossal cyst.

answers.explanation_why: A thyroglossal cyst arises if the thyroglossal duct fails to obliterate completely during embryonal development. The cyst can develop anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct and manifests as a painless, firm, midline mass of the anterior neck. Like the thyroid gland, the thyroglossal cyst is enclosed within the pretracheal fascia, which is responsible for the upward movement of these structures during swallowing. In addition, a thyroglossal cyst moves upward with tongue protrusion because the fibrous remnants of the thyroglossal duct are connected to the base of the tongue.

A ranula is a mucocele arising from the sublingual gland that manifests as a translucent, dome-shaped, blue mass below the tongue. Although large lesions can cause swelling of the neck, this would occur lateral to the midline and would not move upwards with tongue protrusion or swallowing.

Laryngocele, a saccular dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle, can herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and appear as a lateral neck swelling. The neck mass is typically a small, air-filled sac that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver.

A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system in the neck. The neck mass is typically painless, soft, and compressible, and is located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma is associated with fetal aneuploidy (e.g., Turner syndrome).

images.title: Cystic hygroma
images.description: Right lateral region of the neck(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

answers.explanation_why: Dermoid cysts are cystic teratomas that can arise anywhere in the body, including the neck. As a neck mass, they usually manifest at 10–20 years of age as a slow-growing mass in the submandibular or sublingual space.

Branchial cysts can arise if the 2^nd branchial cleft fails to obliterate completely. These neck masses are typically painless and firm, as in this patient, but located lateral to the midline and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not move with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing.

question_text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
hint: The boot-shaped heart on this boy's x-ray is caused by right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). His harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border is caused by pulmonary stenosis. These findings, along with his acute hypoxic spells (which cause cyanosis), indicate a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize right ventricular outflow obstruction.

answers.content: Persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: A persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery characterizes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic heart defect that can cause cyanosis if Eisenmenger syndrome develops. However, patients with a PDA and Eisenmenger syndrome typically develop differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Additionally, PDA causes a continuous, machine-like murmur heard throughout systole and diastole (unlike this patient's systolic murmur), and chest x-ray shows a prominent mediastinum caused by an enlarged pulmonary artery and aortic knob (not a boot-shaped heart).

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Hypoplasia of the left ventricle is caused by hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), a heart condition that is typically acyanotic in the early postnatal period because a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ensures systemic perfusion. Cyanosis develops when the PDA closes, usually within a few days of birth (not as late as 3 months as in this case). Neonates with HLHS also have weak peripheral pulses, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis as the hypoplastic left ventricle cannot maintain adequate cardiac output. Additionally, HLHS does not cause a murmur, and findings on chest x-ray are variable (e.g., small, normal, or enlarged heart and increased pulmonary venous markings) but do not include a boot-shaped heart.

answers.content: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch
answers.explanation_why: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta, manifests variably depending on the degree of aortic stenosis (AS) and the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Patients with significant AS and PDA present with differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Once the PDA closes (usually within a few days after birth), heart failure develops and manifests as dyspnea, sweating during feeds, and poor weight gain. Examination shows pallor (rather than cyanosis), features of inadequate left ventricular output (absent or weak femoral pulses, brachio-femoral delay), and signs of right heart failure (e.g., raised jugular venous pressure, edema, and hepatomegaly). Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary venous markings, not a boot-shaped heart.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why:
Right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) in this patient is caused by pulmonary stenosis, which is one of the components of TOF, along with RVH, an overriding aorta, and a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Exertion, such as crying or feeding, increases the RVOO. This results in cyanosis (tet spells) due to right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD instead of the pulmonary valve, which in turn causes the murmur to become softer. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it chronically pumps against high resistance caused by the RVOO.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during a tet spell. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which increases left ventricular pressure and decreases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the VSD. Infants who are having a tet spell should be placed with their knees toward their chest to achieve the same effect.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Anatomic reversal of aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anatomic reversal of the aorta and pulmonary artery is known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV). This condition causes cyanosis because the aorta arises from the right ventricle and thus results in systemic circulation of deoxygenated blood. However, unlike this patient, cyanosis in TGV manifests immediately after birth. Additionally, chest x-ray in TGV shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to an enlarged heart with a narrowed mediastinum, which resembles an egg lying on its side.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) in infants is usually due to a malformed and displaced tricuspid valve in Ebstein anomaly. These infants may develop cyanosis only if there's an associated ASD or PFO that allows for right-to-left shunting of blood. Auscultation would reveal a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, like in this patient, with a widely split S2. However, a chest x-ray in Ebstein anomaly will show right atrial enlargement (due to chronic reflux of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium) - not a boot-shaped heart as seen in this infant.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

question_text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents because they noticed that his head has been tilted to the left since birth. Physical examination shows the head turned toward the left side and the chin rotated toward the right. He cries during an attempt to rotate the head to the right. There is a firm, well-circumscribed mass on the left lower side of the neck. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents because they noticed that his head has been tilted to the left since birth. Physical examination shows the head turned toward the left side and the chin rotated toward the right. He cries during an attempt to rotate the head to the right. There is a firm, well-circumscribed mass on the left lower side of the neck. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn's head tilt, limited passive range of motion of the neck, and palpable lower neck mass are consistent with a diagnosis of congenital torticollis. The mass seen here is the shortened, thickened segment of the sternocleidomastoid muscle that was injured in-utero or during delivery.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital torticollis, and recall its predisposing factors.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased intrauterine space during pregnancy (e.g., due to fetal macrosomia, multiple gestation, oligohydramnios) is a risk factor for the development of torticollis as it may lead to fetal malpositioning and/or decreased intrauterine fetal movement. In addition, fetal macrosomia, breech presentation, and assisted vaginal delivery can cause perinatal trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscles, which is another risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis.

Cesarean delivery is not a proven risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis. C-section is less likely than assisted vaginal delivery to cause traction to the neonate's neck, which is a known risk factor for congenital torticollis.

Vertex presentation is the most common form of cephalic presentation; it is not a predisposing factor for the development of congenital torticollis. However, breech presentation may lead to congenital torticollis as it has a higher risk of perinatal trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscles during delivery than a vertex presentation.

Dopamine receptor antagonists such as haloperidol can cause acute dystonia, which manifests with torticollis if the sternocleidomastoid muscle is involved. However, dystonic torticollis does not manifest with a palpable mass in the sternocleidomastoid muscle, as seen in this infant.

Polyhydramnios increases intrauterine space; it is not a predisposing factor for the development of congenital torticollis. Oligohydramnios, however, may cause congenital torticollis due to intrauterine restriction of the fetus.

Preterm birth is not a direct risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis. Conditions associated with preterm birth include neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, retinopathy of prematurity, necrotizing enterocolitis, persistent fetal circulation, intracranial hemorrhage, and sepsis.

question_text: A 2600-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 34 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman. The mother did not have prenatal care. Upon examination in the delivery room, the newborn's skin appears blue. He is gasping and breathing irregularly. The ears are low-set with broad auricles, and the nasal tip is flattened. The lower jaw is small and displaced backward. The right foot is clubbed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2600-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 34 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman. The mother did not have prenatal care. Upon examination in the delivery room, the newborn's skin appears blue. He is gasping and breathing irregularly. The ears are low-set with broad auricles, and the nasal tip is flattened. The lower jaw is small and displaced backward. The right foot is clubbed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn presents with low-set ears, flat nose, micrognathia, foot clubbing, and respiratory distress, which suggests Potter sequence. Compression of growing fetal tissue in utero due to oligohydramnios is the underlying etiology for Potter sequence.
learning_objective: Recognize Potter sequence due to posterior urethral valves.

answers.explanation_why: Fetal anemia (e.g., due to alloimmunization in utero) causes a state of high cardiac output, which in turn increases urine production and may subsequently result in polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

Pulmonary hypoplasia is a classic complication of Potter sequence, which results in respiratory distress and cyanosis, as seen in this patient. However, it is not the underlying cause of this patient's overall presentation, but rather the consequence of a problem in the earlier stages of fetal development.

Esophageal atresia causes polyhydramnios because of the fetus' inability to swallow and digest amniotic fluid. Certain types of esophageal atresia that occur in conjunction with tracheoesophageal fistulas may present with respiratory distress as a result of recurrent aspiration. However, esophageal atresia would not explain this patient's facial and limb abnormalities.

Maternal diabetes causes hyperglycemia in both the mother and the fetus. Hyperglycemia in the fetus results in osmotic diuresis and, consequently, increased fetal urine output, which leads to polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. Maternal diabetes is associated with fetal caudal regression syndrome, which is characterized by agenesis of the sacrum and/or lumbar spine, paralysis of the legs, and anal atresia; this is not consistent with this fetus' malformations.

images.title: Caudal regression syndrome
images.description: Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

answers.explanation_why: Fetal anencephaly results in the inability to swallow and digest amniotic fluid, followed by subsequent polyhydramnios. Anencephaly is marked by a severely dysmorphic skull and the absence of a brain, which is (in almost all cases) fatal within the first few hours after birth.

Common causes of oligohydramnios include chronic placental insufficiency, chronic amniotic fluid leakage, and decreased fetal renal output. Prenatal posterior urethral valves lead to a bladder outlet obstruction and a decrease in fetal renal output. Other causes of decreased fetal renal output include bilateral renal agenesis and autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.

The decreased amount of amniotic fluid may result in the development of deformities in the face (Potter facies) and limbs. Oligohydramnios can also affect fetal lung development, resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. This infant's cyanosis and respiratory distress are likely due to pulmonary hypoplasia, which is also the most common cause of death in Potter sequence.

question_text:
A 42-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal examination. She has no history of significant medical illness. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent with a 10-week gestation. Cell-free fetal DNA testing shows a karyotype of 47,XXY. If the fetus's condition had not been diagnosed until puberty, which of the following sets of hormonal changes would most likely be found at that time?

Follicle-stimulating hormone
Luteinizing hormone
Testosterone
Estrogen

A
↑
↑
↓
↑

B
↓
↓
↓
↓

C
↑
↑
normal
normal

D
↑
↑
↑
↓

E
↓
↓
normal
↑
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal examination. She has no history of significant medical illness. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent with a 10-week gestation. Cell-free fetal DNA testing shows a karyotype of 47,XXY. If the fetus's condition had not been diagnosed until puberty, which of the following sets of hormonal changes would most likely be found at that time? Follicle-stimulating hormone Luteinizing hormone Testosterone Estrogen A ↑ ↑ ↓ ↑ B ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ C ↑ ↑ normal normal D ↑ ↑ ↑ ↓ E ↓ ↓ normal ↑
hint: The 47,XXY karyotype is diagnostic of Klinefelter syndrome, which is one of the most common causes of male infertility.
learning_objective: Recognize Klinefelter syndrome, and recall its hormonal findings.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with Klinefelter syndrome have testosterone deficiency beginning at puberty due to testicular dysgenesis. Decreased testosterone levels lead to a loss of the negative feedback loop to the hypothalamus and a compensatory increase in FSH and LH. Increased FSH levels stimulate aromatase synthesis, which leads to increased conversion of testosterone to estradiol. This hormonal imbalance manifests as gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, and a eunuchoid growth pattern. Additional features of Klinefelter syndrome include sparse body hair, azoospermia, and mitral valve prolapse.

This constellation of sex hormones is characteristic of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which is caused by insufficient release of GnRH (hypothalamus) or LH/FSH (pituitary), which leads to deficient levels of testosterone and estrogen. Causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism include intracranial tumors (e.g., craniopharyngioma, prolactinoma), infections, radiation, trauma, and genetic disorders (e.g., Kallmann syndrome).

Patients with unilateral cryptorchidism have normal levels of peripheral sex hormones but increased FSH and LH. Cryptorchidism adversely affects Sertoli cell function, which leads to impaired spermatogenesis and decreased inhibin levels. Leydig cells are unaffected, so testosterone production remains normal. Decreased inhibin levels lead to persistently increased LH and FSH. Klinefelter syndrome manifests with a different pattern of sex hormone disturbance.

Increased gonadotropin levels in combination with increased testosterone and decreased estrogen levels are characteristic of aromatase deficiency. This condition leads to decreased estrogen production with a compensatory increase in FSH and LH (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism). Affected males have normal sexual differentiation, whereas females have ambiguous genitalia at birth and virilization and primary amenorrhea later in life. Klinefelter syndrome manifests with a different pattern of sex hormone disturbance.

Increased peripheral sex hormones and decreased central sex hormones are diagnostic of autonomous excessive sex hormone production. This condition can be caused by sex hormone-producing tumors (e.g., Leydig-cell tumor), McCune-Albright syndrome, some types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and exogenous hormone administration. Patients typically develop precocious puberty. Klinefelter syndrome presents with a different pattern of sex hormone disturbance

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of difficulty swallowing, a foreign body sensation at the back of his throat, and trouble breathing at night. He has just recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection that began 5 days ago. On questioning, he reports that he has had similar symptoms in the past each time he has had an upper respiratory tract infection. Physical examination shows a 3 cm x 2-cm, nontender, rubbery midline mass at the base of the tongue. His skin is dry and cool. An image of his technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of difficulty swallowing, a foreign body sensation at the back of his throat, and trouble breathing at night. He has just recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection that began 5 days ago. On questioning, he reports that he has had similar symptoms in the past each time he has had an upper respiratory tract infection. Physical examination shows a 3 cm x 2-cm, nontender, rubbery midline mass at the base of the tongue. His skin is dry and cool. An image of his technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
hint: The technetium-99m thyroid scan shows radioisotope uptake at the base of the tongue and the hyoid region, but no uptake in the normal location of the thyroid on the anterior neck, findings which suggest an ectopic thyroid gland.
learning_objective: Recognize ectopic thyroid tissue, and recall its developmental origin.

answers.content: Ductal obstruction of the sublingual salivary glands
answers.explanation_why: Ductal obstruction of the sublingual salivary glands would cause backup of secretions, resulting in a mucocele on the floor of the mouth (i.e., a ranula). While this could theoretically cause this patient's dysphagia and dyspnea, it would not explain his abnormal technetium-99m scan.

answers.content: Chronic infection of the palatine and lingual tonsils
answers.explanation_why: Chronic tonsillitis of the palatine and lingual tonsils would cause adenotonsillar hypertrophy. This could be exacerbated by URIs and cause dysphagia and dyspnea, all of which would apply to this patient. However, adenotonsillar hypertrophy does not explain the mass at the base of the tongue or the abnormal uptake on this patient's technetium-99m scan.

answers.content: Arrested endodermal migration from pharyngeal floor
answers.explanation_why: Arrested endodermal migration of the thyroid gland from the pharyngeal floor describes the process by which a thyroglossal duct cyst or ectopic thyroid can arise. This patient's technetium-99m scan shows thyroid tissue within the tongue, the most common location of ectopic thyroid tissue. As in this case, enlargement of ectopic thyroid is common with URIs due to the thyroid's lymphoid tissue and can cause dysphagia and dyspnea. Surgical removal of a lingual thyroid may result in hypothyroidism if there is no other site of thyroid tissue. Some patients with thyroid ectopia develop symptoms of hypothyroidism, which could explain this patient's dry and cool skin.

answers.content: Persistent epithelial tract between the foramen cecum and thyroid isthmus
answers.explanation_why: A persistent epithelial tract between the foramen cecum (tongue) and thyroid isthmus describes the thyroglossal duct. A thyroglossal duct cyst can arise anywhere along this tract and may become enlarged or inflamed after a URI, like with this patient. However, inflammation would be expected at the anterior neck (i.e., midline mass), rather than the tongue. Furthermore, a technetium-99m scan in a patient with a thyroglossal duct cyst would show uptake at the normally positioned thyroid gland, which is not the case here.

answers.content: Failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft
answers.explanation_why: Failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft describes the cause of a branchial cleft cyst. While branchial cleft cysts can result in neck masses, which this patient has, they are usually located laterally and inferior to the pharynx, and also do not typically enlarge following URIs. Furthermore, a branchial cleft cyst does not contain thyroid tissue or explain this patient's abnormal technetium-99m scan.

images.title: Ectopic thyroid tissue
images.description: Nuclear medicine thyroid scan (technetium-99m pertechnetate radioisotope; anterior and lateral views)Increased uptake of radiotracer is visible in the hyoid region and lingual or sublingual regions. There is no uptake in the normal location of the thyroid gland in the anterior neck.The findings indicate two sites of ectopic thyroid tissue. The possibility of ectopic tissue in a thyroglossal duct cyst would also be a consideration for the hyoid region uptake.

question_text: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Initial examination shows a distended abdomen and a flat perineal region without an opening. A dark green discharge is coming out of the vulva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at term. Initial examination shows a distended abdomen and a flat perineal region without an opening. A dark green discharge is coming out of the vulva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This newborn's findings indicate a diagnosis that is commonly part of a constellation of congenital birth defects known as the VACTERL association.
learning_objective: Recognize imperforate anus in a newborn.

answers.explanation_why: Meconium ileus classically presents as abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium within the first 24–48 hours after birth and is commonly observed in patients with cystic fibrosis. However, the absence of an anal opening is inconsistent with meconium ileus. Also, an association of fistula formation with meconium ileus has not been described.

Hirschsprung disease is due to an aganglionic segment leading to uncoordinated peristalsis and spastic contraction of the rectum. It causes functional intestinal obstruction, which results in abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium as seen in this patient. However, examination of affected individuals shows merely an extremely tight sphincter, not the total absence of an anal opening. Also, rectovaginal fistula formation is not a feature of Hirschsprung disease.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

answers.explanation_why: Imperforate anus generally manifests with a poorly developed midline groove between the buttocks and absence of an anal opening. It is commonly associated with fistula formation, which may lead to meconium excretion through a rectovaginal fistula, all of which is observed in this patient. This patient should be closely examined for other possible features of VACTERL association.

images.title: Imperforate anus
images.description: X-ray abdomen (invertogram view) of a newbornA coin has been placed over the anus and the patient has been turned upside down. Multiple dilated gas-filled loops of bowel (examples indicated by green line) are seen proximal to a point of abrupt termination of the distal colon. Beyond this (double arrow), no gas continues to the anus.The appearance is consistent with imperforate anus (anal atresia). The distance between the gas column and the coin can be measured to determine the length of the atretic segment. Imperforate anus can be associated with other congenital abnormalities, among them esophageal atresia, VACTERL association, caudal regression syndrome, trisomy 21, and Currarino triad.

answers.explanation_why: Colonic atresia is a rare congenital malformation that results in colonic obstruction with ensuing abdominal distention. Some patients may also present with delayed passage of meconium after birth as seen in this patient. However, affected individuals have a normal anal opening without fistula formation.

Meconium plug syndrome is a temporary form of intestinal obstruction that manifests with delayed passage of meconium (> 24–48 hours) in combination with abdominal distention. The absence of an anal opening and fistula formation is incompatible with meconium plug syndrome.

question_text: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the emergency room because of 4 episodes of bilious vomiting and inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. An upper GI contrast series shows the duodenojejunal junction to the right of the vertebral midline; an air-filled cecum is noted in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2-week-old infant is brought to the emergency room because of 4 episodes of bilious vomiting and inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. An upper GI contrast series shows the duodenojejunal junction to the right of the vertebral midline; an air-filled cecum is noted in the right upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: The duodenojejunal junction normally lies to the left of the midline, adjacent to the vertebral bodies.
learning_objective: Recognize incomplete intestinal rotation.

answers.explanation_why: Defective neural crest migration to the distal colon results in Hirschsprung disease. The aganglionic segment of the colon fails to relax, which causes functional intestinal obstruction. Although Hirschsprung disease would manifest with bilious vomiting, it also causes significant abdominal distension. Moreover, it typically manifests right after birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours or later in childhood with constipation and abdominal distention.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease in a 5-day-old male newborn
images.description: Distended, bulging abdomen that is tender on palpation. Diagnosis performed by rectal suction biopsy: Hirschsprung's disease

answers.explanation_why: Failure of duodenal recanalization results in duodenal atresia, which would manifest with complete intestinal obstruction at birth. Hallmark imaging findings are the double bubble sign as well as a completely gasless distal small bowel, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, duodenal atresia is associated with maternal polyhydramnios.

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.explanation_why: With complete nonrotation of the intestine, the cecum usually remains in the left lower quadrant. However, this patient's GI series shows a cecum located in the right upper quadrant. Patients with nonrotation may be asymptomatic or present with varying degrees of small bowel obstruction. Radiologically, the small bowel is seen to occupy the right side of the abdomen, with the colon predominantly on the left.

Incomplete intestinal rotation, indicated by a malpositioned duodenojejunal junction (usually located to the left of the midline) and cecum (normally located in the right lower quadrant), can manifest as duodenal obstruction, causing bilious vomiting without abdominal distension. Obstruction is due to extrinsic duodenal compression by peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) that cross over the duodenum to fix the abnormal cecum to the liver or peritoneum.

images.title: Types of volvulus
images.description: The types of volvulus are classified by anatomical location as illustrated here.- Midgut volvulus: A malrotated midgut causing mechanical bowel obstruction, mostly in neonates and infants. Fibrous peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) attaching the cecum to the retroperitoneum are a common pathological finding in midgut volvulus.- Cecal volvulus: The cecum rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.- Sigmoid volvulus: The sigmoid colon rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

answers.content: Arrested rotation of ventral pancreatic bud
answers.explanation_why: An arrested ventral pancreatic bud rotation causes annular pancreas, which can result in extrinsic compression of the duodenum, usually proximal to the major duodenal papilla. Unlike this patient, neonates with annular pancreas typically present with nonbilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Findings on an upper GI series include eccentric or concentric narrowing of the second portion of the duodenum, double bubble sign, and symmetrical dilatation of the proximal duodenum. Moreover, annular pancreas is associated with maternal polyhydramnios.

images.title: Duodenal stenosis from annular pancreas
images.description: Upper GI series (single contrast; lateral view)Narrowing of the second (descending) portion of the duodenum (white arrow) remained fixed during fluoroscopy. A CT scan (not shown) revealed an annular pancreas as the cause.DB: duodenal bulb; S: stomach

answers.content: Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter
answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter lead to pyloric stenosis, which can cause gastric outlet obstruction. Unlike this patient, infants with pyloric stenosis typically present at 2–6 weeks of age with nonbilious vomiting. Other symptoms include early satiety, progressive gastric dilation, weight loss, a succussion splash, and/or hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

images.title: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
images.description: In newborns with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, an enlarged, thickened, olive-shaped, nontender pylorus may be palpable in the epigastrium. The primary symptom of the condition is projectile, nonbilious vomiting immediately after feeding.

answers.content: Resorption of a small bowel segment
answers.explanation_why: Jejunal atresia and ileal atresia occur as a result of resorption of a small bowel segment thought to be caused by an in-utero vascular disruption that leads to ischemic necrosis of the fetal intestine. The necrotic tissue is resorbed, leaving blind proximal and distal ends, often with a gap in the mesentery. Although neonates may present with bilious vomiting as in this case, jejunal/ileal atresia would also cause a distension of the upper abdomen, delayed meconium passage, and a triple bubble sign on x-ray. Moreover, jejunal/ileal atresia has been associated with maternal polyhydramnios.

images.title: Triple bubble sign in jejunal atresia
images.description: X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomitingDilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level
